Celebrating International Womenâ€™s Day

By Hannah Boyle

Orla McAndrew reflects on this important day and speaks to other editors and writers about who inspires them

Young writers: too tame?

Debate ensued this year as playwright Athol Fugard spoke out criticising young writers for their apparent inability to write about morally weighty subjects. In his opinion the theatre world is lacking "committed playwrights who are prepared to bear witness to what is going on every bit as urgently as the old ones did"

Nouse Playlist

Inspired by how naturally Biggie and Elton, Missy and The Doors are mixed by mash-up godfather Girl Talk, we have gone a step further and found the best (or is that worst) metal covers of pop songs

Affiliations: sites of inscription

Isabelle Wynne reviews the latest exhibition on at Norman Rea's Gallery

Top 5 Movie Assassins

To celebrate the release of Machete and The American, we explore cinema's five most formidable hitmen

Leeds Film Festival 2010

Gareth Davies & Michael Allard check out the selection on at the international film scene in Leeds this year

Cafe No. 8

What to do as a student on a Saturday night? 'Salvation, Tokyo and Ziggy's' are full of the over thirties/lonely hearts and apparently no one (particularly YUSU) likes Gallery anymore

The American

It's marketed as an action-thriller, but it's not; for a film about an assassin on his last job, there's surprisingly little action. Most of the suspenseful sequences reach an underwhelming conclusion, and the traditional American firing range is replaced with a picturesque forest clearing in Italy

Pub

Sometimes you just know you're going to have a good night. Walking towards <strong>The Maltings</strong> last Thursday I bumped into none other than Brendan Sheerin, of Coach Trip fame. To say I was star struck would be an understatement

Machete

Unless you have accidentally stumbled into the wrong screen, it is more than likely that you know what you're getting when you step into <em>Machete</em>

Bettys & Taylors of Harrogate

How to make the perfect cup of tea

Rocking Out the Media Storm

Sam Briggs talks to NME's latest cover star The Vaccines (Thumbnail credit The Vaccines hitting the road)

Tropical punks: An Interview with Abe Vigoda

Adam Bychawski asks Abe Vigoda about cold wave

Champagne Charlie: Royal Icing

I've always had a soft spot for the Royal Family. I know that they are expensive, arguably unnecessary and at times outright bizarre, but then many of my favourite things (violet creams, cowboy boots etc) also fall into that category

Ziggy's by Numbers

Ziggy's by Numbers

Future Sounds

A band's MySpace can be deceiving, for a start, laughing off Melody of your Demise is too easy, especially with claims of "tearing a niche into the local scene" and song titles like 'Judi Dench Battles the Rancor'

Camilla Jenkins Investigates: the Thanksgiving hype

Camilla Jenkins Investigates: the Thanksgiving hype

Pantheon

Catching the final notes of Lost Effect, York seems to be the ideal location for a band that sound like a frustrated gang of vikings fronted by Amy Lee

Le Trio Joubran

We were promised an evening of 'musical genius, profound ideas about history, and the beauty of art' and not only were these proclamations fulfilled, they were excelled

Politician gone rogue?

By James Bithell

Just when the media had him typecast as a political flipflopper, John Bercow gave up party affiliations. Camilla Jenkins and Liv Evans talk to the new Speaker of the House of Commons to find out whether he's as unpredictable as they say (Thumbnail credit Speaker of the House of Commons John Bercow opens the first session of Youth Parliament at the House of Commons)

Songs from the slums

By James Bithell

Sophie Walker investigates El Sistema, the social phenomenon that has made Venezuela rich in spirit (Thumbnail credit The Simon Bolivar Youth Orchestra of Venezuela in rehearsal with their conductor, Gustavo Dudamel)

Books and Babies

By James Bithell

Teenage pregnancy is commonly dismissed as irresponsible. Hannah Ellis-Petersen examines the reality behind the stereotype

In the sky with diamonds

By James Bithell

Mia de Graaf talks to the fans, followers, and impersonators of Liverpool's lost star marking the 30th anniversary of his death

Behind the red curtain

By James Bithell

Edward Grande talks to Alastair Whatley, Creative Director of the Original Theatre Company, about his life in a touring theatre (Thumbnail credit All photos: The Original Theatre Company)

Campus Snapshots

By James Bithell

Campus Snapshots (Thumbnail credit Image: Flickr/Facebook)

Band of the Week: Comus

By James Bithell

Resident sound-nerd <em>Tom Killingbeck</em> thumbs through reams of musty vinyl so you don't have to. Here are his weekly recommendations...

Jeanne Roberts

Achieving originality in the world of art is notoriously difficult. In fact, it is arguably impossible (Thumbnail credit Margaret, by Jeanne Roberts)

A Hybrid World

When must the line be drawn between technology and the process of artistic creation, if at all?

Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1

It's never good when you emerge from a cinema thinking "is that it?" Of course, with <em>Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 1</em>, this was sort-of inevitable; any reader of the final book knows that there isn't a comfortable cut-off point around the middle, and as such the ending of this film tries its hardest to find a cliff-hanger, but ultimately comes up short

The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged!)

The Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged!) is ambitious, fun, dramatic, and pushes the boundaries of how we view traditional Shakespearean theatre.

Due Date

First, director Todd Phillips made a name for himself with <em>Road Trip</em>. Then, following a decade-long detour by way of the Frat Pack, he made <em>The Hangover</em>, a film which made a lot of people laugh, particularly at the revelatory comic persona of Zach Galifianakis, and also made a huge profit

Young writers: too tame?

Debate ensued this year as playwright Athol Fugard spoke out criticising young writers for their apparent inability to write about morally weighty subjects. In his opinion the theatre world is lacking "committed playwrights who are prepared to bear witness to what is going on every bit as urgently as the old ones did"
